questions.question_text: Which of the following channels would commonly be used on an 802.11 wireless network?

discussion.content: The letters after 802.11 are pretty important and relevant to networking. Make sure to memorize the different perks/uses of 802.11 systems such as ac, g, n, and more. CompTIA covers a range of technology and on the job you'll encounter old and new stuff frequently. Knowledge goes a long way in tackling issues.

802.11b, 802.11g, 802.11n, or any wireless access points that run 2.4 GHz frequencies can only use channels between 1 and 11. For this question the answer is obvious but if they told you to pick a channel between 1 - 11, you should always pick 1, 11, or 6 first because they prevent interference and ensure non-overlapping of the channel.

choices.E: Use static IP addressing instead of DHCP.
choices.A: Set the NIC to full duplex.

questions.question_text: A user received the following error message while trying to access a shared drive: Network Path was Not Found. Which of the following should be performed to resolve the issue? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
I believe the answer is to Reset TCP/IP and Disable Local firewalls. Lifewire talks about these solutions here: https://www.lifewire.com/network-path-was-not-found-3971341

When you use the "netsh" command to reset the TCP/IP and reboot the OS, it will return Windows to a clean state

As for disabling the local firewalls, temporarily disabling the firewall will help you figure out if a firewall is preventing your network from sharing properly

comments.content: Hmm, actually I think I am wrong. The question is asking to resolve the issue not identify. Reset TCP/IP and clearing the DNS cache are actual solutions that solve this issue.

discussion.content: i was so stoked i got this question hahaha

When I read share-drive, I associated with the path on a local network. But the options listed here are more about accessing a remote-shared drive. In this link talks about the symptoms of a corrupted tcp/ip stack (OSI model) as well as the corrupted/malfunctioning DNS.
Answer: tcp/ip reset & dns flushing

questions.question_text: A client brings in a smartphone with a cracked screen to be repaired. During the repair process, the technician places the screws in a small container to prevent losing them. The technician tests the replacement screen to ensure it works property before closing the device. Once the device is back together, however it does not power on.

choices.C: Document the orientation of the cables.
choices.A: Label the locations of the screws.

discussion.content: Umm..... What's the question? I don't see a question mark anywhere.

THIS IS THE WHOLE QUESTION: A client brings in a smartphone with a cracked screen to be repaired During the repair process, the technician places the screws in a small container to prevent losing them. The technician tests the replacement screen to ensure it works properly before dosing the device. Once the device is back together however it does not power on. The technician disassembles the device once again to test the screen and finds it has shorted out Which of the following disassembly procedures should the technician have followed to prevent this from occurring? AND THE ANSWER IS : A. LABEL THE LOCATION OF THE SCREWS.... This I retrieved from another site.... you're welcome!

comments.content: So are you trying to say it's how it asked in CompTIA exam?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
probably messed up the power connection.

comments.content: it is common for a screw to double as a ground

discussion.content: why is C not an answer? screws don't affect device power do they?

Selected Answer: A
It is necessary to fix this question, it seems that it is incomplete. What do they know what to know in reality? Is this taken from a real exam?
Maybe they shortened the "question" to a statement so that B becomes the answer but mentioning screw locations still hints to A.

If this is the Full Question:
A client brings in a smartphone with a cracked screen to be repaired During the repair process, the technician places the screws in a small container to prevent losing them. The technician tests the replacement screen to ensure it works properly before dosing the device. Once the device is back together however it does not power on. The technician disassembles the device once again to test the screen and finds it has shorted out Which of the following disassembly procedures should the technician have followed to prevent this from occurring?
THEN by the Nature of COMPTIA questions it stated: "places the screws in a small container" This was stated for a reason, I know COMPTIA making this overcomplicated but Documenting and labeling screws would be the answer the question is hinting on.
No questions asked (takes on a whole new meaning here).
This is an incident not a question
Document the location of the cable. why because the question ask for disassembling procedure, which involve document the location.

comments.content: nvm, the answer is A. I missed the keyword " disassembly procedures". During a disassembly procedure, you should always document and label your screws/location regardless if you read the manual or not.

Yup this is the actual question as I saw from another exam dump. 

I am going with B. It is essential to read the owner's manual before you start anything. If no documentation then you will need to document all the screws and locations yourself.

discussion.content:
This is the full question:

A client brings in a smartphone with a cracked screen to be repaired During the repair process, the technician places the screws in a small container to prevent losing them. The technician tests the replacement screen to ensure it works properly before dosing the device. Once the device is back together however it does not power on. The technician disassembles the device once again to test the screen and finds it has shorted out Which of the following disassembly procedures should the technician have followed to prevent this from occurring?
Refer to manufacturer is not a solution
It could be "A", or "B"; but "A" is the better answer because if you put the same screw that came out of somewhere there's no reason that it wouldn't work like you want it to.
this site is stating the correct answers is B but others sites saying that the correct answer is A !!!

comments.content: It could be either or. I say the answer is A since the question already stated that the screws were placed in a container to prevent them being lost or misplaced. But sometimes that could be worded wrong too. The user could've misplaced them by accident without putting labels on and that could've been the cause of the phone not working. However, since it kind of stated that nothing was wrong with putting the screws back in. Choice B is the most logical answer.

discussion.content: A client brings in a smartphone with a cracked screen to be repaired. During the repair process, the technician places the screws in a small container to prevent losing them. The technician tests the replacement screen to ensure it works property before closing the device. Once the device is back together, however it does not power on. What should the Technician do?
What is the question?!?!?!
Question is not good at all
HUH? This is a weird and vague question..

port fowarding
according with pcmag
Also called "port mapping," port forwarding is directing traffic from the outside world to the appropriate server inside a local TCP/IP network. Internet services are identified by a standard port number; for example, Web traffic uses port number 80. If the local network hosts a Web server that is accessible on the public Internet, the port forwarding panel in the router would be configured to direct Web/HTTP packets (port 80 traffic) to the IP address of the Web server in the local network (LAN).

questions.question_text:
A technician is setting up a new SOHO router for a home user. The user has a media server to be accessible from the Internet while the user is traveling.
Which of the following should the technician configure to allow access to the server from the Internet?

discussion.content:
Reinstalling the print driver on the print server is the most correct answer because this is an interface issue common with multiple users.
If a user account had insufficient permissions, they would be unable to print.
Updating the firmware of the printer is unnecessary because there is nothing wrong with the printer itself.
Conducting Windows updates is inappropriate because this invites greater security and system stability concerns that would need to be addressed by department management. This course of action is too broad to address this individual issue.

The only question is, "How many computers are affected?" If it's every computer then reinstalling the print driver on the print server would be the best, but if it's a few then maybe running windows update would help.

Reinstalling the print driver on the print server is the most correct answer because this is an interface issue common with multiple users.
If a user account had insufficient permissions, they would be unable to print.
Updating the firmware of the printer is unnecessary because there is nothing wrong with the printer itself.
Conducting Windows updates is inappropriate because this invites greater security and system stability concerns that would need to be addressed by department management. This course of action is too broad to address this individual issue.

comments.content:

questions.question_text:
Users report they have to select the output tray at the printer, even though the correct tray is selected in the print dialog.
Which of the following should a technician perform FIRST to attempt to solve the problem?

choices.C: Update the firmware on the commercial office printer.
choices.B: Reinstall the driver on the print server.
choices.A: Check the user's account for the correct printing privileges.
choices.D: Run Windows Update on the affected computers.
